We lived in Rome when my 93 year old mother in law came to visit us. For reference, we lived across from the Villa Borghese museum, so outside the historic district but still relatively close.
For one day, we hired a private guide and booked a car service. My mother in law had a rolling walker. The driver took us to Piazza Venizia. The guide walked with us, at my mother in law’s pace, down the avenue (vehicles are not allowed), past the forum towards the Colosseum. The guide gave us a commentary about everything, and you can see a lot from the road, so that was interesting for my mother in law and her friend. The car and driver met us by the arch near the Colosseum and drove us to the Circus Maximus. Again, more explanation from the guide. Then the driver took us to the Pantheon and was able to get us within 50 yards of the site. We had our visit there and then did the same thing at the Spanish steps. I believe we spent about 6 hours total. It was fairly expensive to do this, but worth it to us. I think the same thing could be done with a good tour guide and taxis. It really helped that the guide was communicating with the driver about the exact places to drop us off and pick us up. I know some Italian but even having lived in Rome for a couple of years at that point, I didn’t know enough about the city to be able to precisely indicate where I wanted to go. And the commentary was wonderful because we weren’t rushed and could just listen.
On another day, I booked a private tour of the Vatican. I let them know about my MILs capabilities and they took us in early, borrowed a wheelchair from the museum and the guide pushed the wheelchair through the museum. There are elevators that the guides can use for disabled guests. The only problem was that you can’t get from the Sistine Chapel to St. Peter’s without using stairs so we had to exit the way we entered.
Another day, we took a taxi to Piazza Navona. The driver was wonderful. I just asked to get us as close as possible to the Piazza. I expected to be taken to the nearest taxi stand (which I was familiar with), but she went down tiny side streets and dropped us at the base of the square just steps from one of the fountains.
Another day, we took a taxi to the Colosseum with the idea of just getting a few photos and perhaps doing a short walk around the area (more for my MULs friend) and while we we taking photos, someone from the Colosseum staff came and took us to a special entrance for the disabled, so we paid the regular fee and went into the Colosseum - no line! There is an elevator inside, so although wheelchairs can’t go everywhere, you can get some great views and have a good experience.
There are blogs about accessibility in Italy, and I found one before their visit that really helped to identify hotels and restaurants that were appropriate.
Sorry for the long post but I thought my experience might help you. There are things you can do with someone in a wheelchair in Rome, but driving yourself is not practical because of parking problems and traffic and frankly, you will be able to get much closer if dropped off by a taxi.

Rome (FCO) airport - Tax refund tips.

We returned from a lovely tour of Italy couple of weeks ago. We secured tax refund on our purchase at the Rome FCO airport.

Sharing some info that might be useful for members of this group.

What is the percentage of tax you can claim?

It depends on the item you have purchased and what arrangement the retailer has with the the 'tax refund company' such as Global Blue etc. We had items for which the refund was 15% while for a high value item we got 18%.

When to claim refund?

Option 1: After security the check:

Complete the check in, have the boarding pass, clear security and passport control. You must have the items and invoice with you. Go to customs counter near the security gates and show the items and get the invoice stamped. Then go to the refund company counter to get the refund.

We did not do this option as we felt there are couple of problems with this option:

- Once you clear the security you will only have say an hour or so for your flight. Based your flight time of the day, there will be a LONG queue in front of the customs and refund company counters. In the worst scenario you may have to give up on your refund as you don't want to miss the flight!

- refund will be to your credit card only (no cash). The actual refund transaction takes place after several weeks (this is what we were told). Should there be a dispute or discrepancy you are helpless to resolve as you won't be in Italy. Risky.

We were carrying items costing in five digits and refund was in four digits. We didn't want to take risk so we took the below option:

Option 2: Before the security check:

- Arrive at the airport few hours early.
Have your boarding pass (we did online check in the previous day and had our boarding passes in our email.) So don't go to your airline counter to check in the bags.

- Head straight to the refund company counter first. They are in all terminals and ours was in T3 (see pics below). Show the invoice and the boarding pass.
For any not-so-high value item they won't (for us they did not) insist on customs stamp to make refund. You have a choice of refund by cash or refund to your card. They charge a very small fee for cash refund.

- For the high value item we had, we went to the customs counter and showed the item and the boarding pass, got the invoice stamped and then went to the refund counter. Promptly got the cash refund. We kept our items in the check-in luggage. We then went to our airline counter and dropped out bags.

It took us about half an hour for the whole process.

This option gave us the peace of mind and was less stressful. We were glad we completed all this before security as there was very long queue for refund after security (option 1).

In the free time we had before boarding we enjoyed some more Italian food and of course some great wine!

Hope this info is useful. Please note this was our experience and might be different to others.

“Beaches in Italy: What to Know Before You Go”

By Karen in Calabria

When a country is almost entirely surrounded by water, as is the case with Italy, it stands to reason that beaches are a big deal. There are beaches of varying degrees of wonderful up and down both sides of The Boot, and the vast majority of Italians grow up with the understanding that part of every summer involves time spent at the shore.

It sounds idyllic, no?

Traveling to Italy in summer is the perfect time to get in on this Italian beach culture, not least because it can be agonizingly hot and humid in the cities. Spontaneity when planning a summer trip to an Italian beach isn’t usually a good thing, however. Those who plan ahead in this department are the ones who reap the rewards.
Which is why you’re here, you clever planner, you.

So, here’s what you need to know about the beaches in Italy, before you don your suit and head for the sand.

"Private" beaches in Italy

I’ve spent most of my life in Oregon, where all beaches are public by law. For me, then, this is one of the aspects of Italian beach culture that surprised me most.

While, technically, the beaches themselves are “public” (and the strip of land right at the water’s edge is certainly that), there are concessions (called “stabilimenti” or “bagni”) at nearly every stretch of sand that have bought permits from local authorities to set up rows and rows of beach chairs (“lettini,” or beds) and umbrellas (“ombrelle”) that they then rent out. Again, technically, while anyone should be able to walk to the water from further up on the beach, the bagni are usually set up so close together – one group of colored umbrellas abutting the next – that passing between them is impossible. And walking through one of them without paying isn’t permitted by the folks running that particular concession.

You may hear about protestors fighting this, demanding more access to beaches, but it doesn’t seem to change the status quo.

So, if you choose to pay for the privilege of hanging out on an Italian beach, what do you get for your money? Quite a bit, actually. Not only do you have a comfy lounge chair and shade-providing umbrella set up for you (without the need to lug one around yourself), you are also granted access to the facilities at the stabilimento – usually including changing rooms, showers, toilets, places to store your clothes, and places to get food and beverages. There are also typically lifeguards on duty.

You can choose just a chair, or a chair with an umbrella, for different fees – and if you’ll be in town for awhile, you can also buy a pass good for a longer period of time. Many Italians have annual rentals at the same bagni, where they get a monthly pass – and therefore the best spots. And yes, when you pay for access to the private beach you’ll be directed toward a chair – you don’t get to choose.

"Public" Beaches in Italy

The rest of the beaches in Italy are entirely public, and therefore free. These are, perhaps unsurprisingly, not always as nice, clean, or well-maintained as the “private” beaches. You can look for signs indicating which beaches or parts of the beach are free (look for the words “spiaggia libera”), but it’s a good bet that the areas without orderly rows of umbrellas and loungers are public beaches.

There’s a huge variance among public beaches in terms of what amenities are available. Some of them have public toilets and showers. There are often beachside restaurants or kiosks nearby, even if they’re just temporary affairs set up for the summer months. Sometimes, however, there is simply a stretch of sand (or pebbles) and that’s it. In many cases, access to the public beach is via a long staircase from a parking area up above, so be prepared for something of a hike. If you’re unfamiliar with the area, it’s a good idea to inquire about the facilities before you head out, lest you arrive for a day at the beach without necessary provisions.

It’s also a good idea to keep a close eye on your belongings, especially on busy public beaches. These are not monitored by anyone, so would-be pickpockets and petty thieves sometimes meander through looking for easy targets. Make sure it’s not you.

Italian Beach Attire

Perhaps you’re familiar with the often-comically-portrayed stereotype of old Italian men at the beach in Speedos, letting a lifetime’s worth of pasta gut all hang out. Stereotypes usually have at least some basis in fact, and – yes – those guys exist. In fact, the Speedo-type suit is still de rigeur for many older Italian (and European) men. More common these days, however, especially for younger men, are swim trunks.

For women of all ages, a bikini or two-piece is the way to go. One-piece suits are something of a rarity on Italian beaches, no matter one’s age or body type. (Italian women think “bikini body” means “any body on which you put a bikini,” which is a million kinds of wonderful, if you ask me.)

In some parts of Italy, topless sunbathing is common and not restricted to certain beaches or areas – bare breasts not being seen as the taboo that they seem to be in the United States. Nude sunbathing, however, is usually restricted to certain areas that may or may not be specially-designated as nude beaches (they may be unofficially categorized as such, in that locals all know where the invisible boundary is). If you’re looking for (or trying to avoid) a nude beach, ask around. And before you take off your top on any beach, it’s a good idea to make sure you’re not the only one doing so – just in case you’re in a part of the country where that’s not such an accepted norm. As in many other situations, best practice is to follow the lead of the locals.

Italy is nothing if not fashionable, and that extends to beach vacations. Even in beach towns, you won’t see people walking into restaurants or shops wearing flip-flops or bikini tops. Beach attire is for the beach, and that’s that. Men, top off your stylish (and dry) swim trunks with an equally-stylish tee shirt. Women, put on a pretty sundress or beach cover-up dress over your swimsuit. And everyone, swap the plastic beach sandals for something a bit nicer.

August on an Italian Beach

Many Italians and other Europeans get about a month of vacation time each summer, often in August. And if you’ve ever seen an Italian beach in August, you might think every single last one of them spends that vacation on a beach in Italy.

Yeah, beaches in Italy in August are crowded.
Remember earlier when I said that as fun as a spontaneous day trip to that pretty Italian beach in August sounds, it isn’t necessarily a good idea? This is why. Because so many people spend a few weeks at the seaside every single summer, you bet they’ve booked well in advance – everything from their hotel or apartment to their beach chairs.

This isn’t to say that you shouldn’t go to the beach in the summer if you’re in Italy – far from it. It just means that you’ll be far happier doing so if you can plan ahead a bit. Book lodging in advance, and – if you can – arrange for spots at a stabilimento. Make your time at the beach as relaxing as it ought to be with a little advance legwork.

Blue Flag Beaches

The Blue Flag program is a global environmental effort that gives out its Blue Flag awards to beaches and marinas that meet its list of more than 30 criteria (including water quality, services available, and overall safety). There are so-called Blue Flag beaches all over the world, including many in Italy.

The list of Blue Flag beaches in Italy changes periodically, as the sites are regularly evaluated by the organization, with existing beaches removed and new ones added.

These are the things they said they liked: Vespa with side car tour of Florence, Bernini express into Switzerland, golf cart tour rome, gelato and pizza making class in Florence, Rome colosseum night tour, lucca bike tour, private boat rentals in Como and Amalfi and jumping off cliffs in Como, Sorrento, and caves.
Plan a couple of down days to rest.
Give yourself time if you are transferring trains - they are often late and you don’t want to miss your connecting train.
We went from Amalfi to Rome and on our travelling day we stopped in Pompeii, stored our luggage, took a tour and then went to Rome.
Do not skip Venice!! It was my favorite!

I spent 2 weeks just in Rome—and Florence and visited many museums, was absolutely delighted. My heart was full—yes, It depends on your interest. I’m a museum freak. I’d say 2 days in Venice and you’ve seen it all. Capri is gorgeous.
That sounds like a good time share.

Venice is the most remarkable place in the world...you'd be crazy to miss it. Florence is only 2 hours from there...and work your way down to naples Rome etc.

To start your trip in the North would be so spectacular. Fly into marco polo airport. Go to the airport dock and jump in a speedboat taxi ... its not cheap BUT I PROMISE you its a memory you will keep forever ...and it WILL impress even the most disinterested teenager...they
ll never forget it!! Costs 130 to 150 euros ... no need to book. The speedboat will take you direct to venice ... if you book a hotel with a dock ( I've stayed at many but hotel columbina is a pretty little boutique hotel with a dock)...you will arrive like movie stars. And you'll see and be utterly delighted by the views of venice ... I swear! At night being in san marco Square ( that hotel is 2 minutes away) is magical ... music playing ...the lights! And it's safe ... its a safe place to wander ( usual annoying rose sellers etc). Venice will be the highlight of your trip! From venice to travel just go to the train station and travel to Florence so easily. Lovely train station...right
In the center ...as everything is in venice. I was there in march weather was fine ... not cold not hot...just take layers.

You may find it a bit cheaper in salerno and very easy to get to pompeii etc by bus plus easy access to rome and florence .book with booking.com for hotels as many of them are pay at property.umbria
and tuscany are wonderful too have a great trip we got the ferry to capri aswell
Check out Republic of San Marino 🇸🇲in province of Emilia Romana; third smallest country in the world. Beautiful

Skip Venice. Stick to this itinerary with only 2 weeks. Your days will be FULL! Venice does not fit geographically and you cant spend all your time getting to places. Driving through Tuscany is fun! Chianti!!! ❤️Book yourselves a family lunch at a small local farm to table venue. We literally went to the home of a family that makes wine, olive oil, honey, and farms all kinds of produce. The wife cooked us a delicious lunch and we ate on their gorgeous outdoor vine covered patio. Ive not been in March. I did not care for Sorrento. Too crowded. Stay in Positano and use the ferry system to see other Amalfi towns.

Hello, I know Pienza and the surrounding area quite well. I would take a train to Florence or Siena and rent a car from there.
Also, I would stay at least 3 nights .
If you have never been, there is so much to see and do.
Check HOTEL POSTA MARCUCCI in BAGNO VIGNONI (a day at their spa water pools overlooking the valley!)
San Quirico d'Orcia, cappella di Vitaleta,Montal
cino (Caffè Poliziano, incredible view..you can spot lake Trasimeno in the distance) , Monticchiello..

I STRONGLY advise you not to pick up your hired car in the centre of Rome, particularly not at the rail station. The cars are parked at multi story car parks often a good distance from the station and finding them and then your way out of Rome can be a nightmare. Worth the cost and effort to take a taxi or public transport to Fiumicino airport and pick up the car there and get straight onto the main highways

These are all great suggestions but to motivate teens you need to hit their sweet spot - and I don’t mean gelato - although that helps.
Have a list which everyone wants to see and do- what your interests are.
History/ art / food/ geography and those that align then concentrate from there. Or if your interests are completely different select some from everyone’s list as it gets everyone feeling more involved.
Then group them together.
Pompeii, Vesuvius and Herculaneum for example are nicely together. Naples is the place to land for those. But in March Vesuvius maybe closed due to weather.
Sorrento, capri etc but as the weather is not certain it maybe one to miss this time.

Venice is beautiful- the vaporetto is just hop on and hop off- the islands if Murano and Burano and just artisan central.
Verona is a small train ride away. So it’s very arty. We did the opera in Venice lovely.
They do opera in Verona, the shops are lovely and they have their own colosseum.

Florence - David is wow, the shopping is great the history is seeped into the walls. Areas are out Florence are stunning and of course Pisa is a short bus or train ride away.

Rome is just Rome- no words describe Rome, to me it is magic. Every time I go I see something I missed last time
The colosseum and yes take the tour! Go on the arena and go underneath, the tour normal includes the Roman Forum and the Palatine hill.
Architecture is just amazing, the Pantheon, Villa Borghese, the Vatican (even kids love the map rooms and the seagulls history that is depicted. The Sistine chapel. Piazza Navona.
Great gelato everywhere.
Of course the Trevi.
They do not call it the eternal city for nothing.

But we all have different tastes and go according to your family.

My teen when we went was desperate to do Pompeii and climb Vesuvius. So I had it planned right Naples base. Then the joy said and the colosseum I have to see the colosseum…. Humpf.
So changed to basing in Rome and a very long day trip to Vesuvius and Pompeii- we slept well!

It will all be magical if you hit your sweet spot. It saves you being disappointed as everyone’s tastes differ and also depends on the time of year.
Keep planning.

I just got back from 3 weeks in Italy (June) staying in Rome, Florence, Positano, and Lake Como. I think 3 full days in Rome is great, you wouldn’t want any less as it is an amazing walkable city. Best location to stay is near Pantheon/ Piazza Navona/ Campo de’ Fiori areas…you can reach all the major attractions on foot, incl Spanish Steps. Florence/ Tuscany was one of the biggest highlights for me and it’s a great base to explore further. Staying in Florence you can do a day trip to Cinque Terre (amazing hikes), Pisa, Siena, San Gimignano and so many more. Definitely prioritise Florence/ Tuscany. I don’t know that you would get the best out of Amalfi for that time of year. It’s amazing but it’s at its best in the warmer months. You could do a day trip to Pompeii from Rome. Also, the high speed trains in Italy are exceptional and a great option to get to your next stop. Have a great time, travelling in Italy is the bees knees 👌🏼

In may 2023, I spent a month in Italy! never enough time!￼🥹 but I would skip Naples and add that day or two to Venice. You will never regret it! Venice has an atmosphere or vibe if you want to call it…that exist nowhere else in Italy, imho. ￼ I was a solo traveler for a month, never once felt afraid how are you will see lots of posts about pickpockets.🤦🏻‍♀️ I can’t even tell you I was always aware of my surroundings is when should be, but I always kept my purse zippers toward my body! Never issue you all love every second of your trip, no matter where you go! Absolutely fascinating country with an incredible train system! I think I spent three or four days in Venice, if you do make it there, do not miss Saint Marks Square and splurge on some thing at the Florian café! An Italian classic! I took the train from there to Milan and flew out of Milan! ￼ I literally gasp as I stepped out of the taxi at the Duomo! ￼ The most magnificent building I think I’ve seen in my life! But again I did have more time than you! Regardless of what you see, and where are you go, just melt into the culture, take it easy as the Italians do! sit too long at the outdoor cafés, if you can in March, have an espresso, cappuccino before noon only, and do not miss ￼those Aperol spritz! I am not a drinker at all, but loved those had way too many that month, but that’s what you do when your in Italy! Have fun above all, have fun
Ravelling amazing….
Ravello………

What a beautiful time to travel here! In the Amalfi area, Maiori is a close town that is lower in price, has more restaurants and shops, and only a 10-15min ferry ride to Amalfi. If the parking garage near Amalfi is open by then (has been closed the past few months) then you can drive 10 minutes there. We love staying in Maiori (hike the Path of Lemons!) instead of Amalfi or Sorrento (too touristy and more relaxing and costs less). Plus a short ferry gets you around if you don’t drive. There is also a hike between Ravello and Scala.
Why not incorporate a day in Naples (1hr10mins with fast train from Rome ) or go to Bologna (1hr 55mins with fast train )

March is a good time to go! We are going g to Rome, Florence and Tuscany late March to avoid the crowds and heat. Italy has a moderate climate, much like CA so I think it will get fine. But I think 5 days in Rome might be too long. You could add Sorrento in Southern Italy. We went last April it was beautiful, weather mostly sunny in the 60s.
Venice is so unique. I wouldn't miss it. Add as much time as you possibly can. You won't want to leave. (Seriously!)

Italy is best seen in sections, so you can take in as much as possible. Naples-South, Florence-Naples
, or Florence-North.
You can see/do more without wasting precious time traveling far. If this is a once in a lifetime trip, set priorities of your must-sees, then knock them off the list.
More Tuscany, less Amalfi because of the weather.

We just did almost this schedule and it was great! We did go to Venice, and it wasn’t our favorite. We had our two teenage daughters with us, they had a couple days that they stayed at the hotel or at the beach in Cinque Terre where they hung out at the pool and beach while my husband and I hiked and in Tuscany drove around to wineries and had a great lunch. I would try to find hotel/lodging that might have something for them to do if you allow them to be alone any time.

I don't think you can go wrong any time or with any itinerary.

We went the first 2 weeks in April this year and the weather quite chilly, with a little rain and wind. Because it was spring break/Easter things were also quite crowded. We still had an amazing time, including my 15 year old son and 5 year old daughter.

We flew into to Milan and out of Rome. A thing I didn't realize until almost too late was how early things book up in advance. I was still able to get tickets to everything we wanted, but sometimes had to choose tours over just buying tickets and also had some tickets too close together to not feel rushed (only 2 hours in the Uffizi Gallery, Florence , for instance). Still amazing and worth all the stress.

Sorrento was great! It's relaxing and laid back, with not so many stairs to climb as some of the Amalfi coast towns. Pompeii was a bucket list item for both me and my husband and the kids were both interested as well. Ercalano/
Herculaneum is maybe even cooler, though and they are both on the same train line. We saw them both on the same day - it was a lot of walking - and I'd do it again in a heartbeat. Da Fillipos was fantastic for Easter lunch. https://
www.facebook.com
/dafilippo1983/ And our host's son owns https://
www.facebook.com

radicalsorrento which was great for brunch (kids got pancakes and bacon which they had missed a little bit).

We stayed in Bologna at firs to visit it and because it's a quick train ride to both Venice and Florence which we did as day trips. We drove down the Adriatic coast to Atri because my husband's family is from a nearby mountain village. I knew nothing about Abruzzo before planning the trip, but it was spectacularly beautiful and has some great hiking. You drive right through the Appinine mountains to get to Sorrento or Rome and that was pretty cool.

If you're driving a long way, I have to say that lunch at Autogrill on the Autostrada was not at all a hardship. I didn't expect to enjoy eating my first meal in Italy (at least in the last 30 years) at a rest stop, but immigration took forever, we needed to get to our Airbnb to check in, and decided to give it a try. Made fresh in front of you, tasty, and fast. It's only low quality compared to all the other amazing places you'll eat in Italy, but still better than many high end Italian restaurants in the US.

I really enjoyed the planning and had spreadsheets of alternative itineraries. Rick Steven's message boards and videos are also a great resource.
Venice, Rome and Florence are a must for first trip. Two weeks in Italy not enough!

First thing is, stay with the itinerary you have chosen because that is what you want to see. Having people say take a day here or a night here or add this or subtract that, that is well and fine but based on their experiences. Second, work with your teenagers on what they to see-family affair. Each person has the 1 thing that is the most important thing to see. Third, do your research. I recommend Romewise and Florencewise -on FB and YouTube, Rick Steves book on Italy. For Rome, plot on a map the most important places you want to visit and get a hotel that is most central. The Monti area or the Pantheon area is good. You will be doing a lot of walking and you need to plan efficiently to make the most of your visit. Fourth, plot in the travel time from each location and then see how much time is really left. Example is Pienza, which is wonderful and I am sure you will love it but, a lot of travel for 1 day. Figure out what is so important in Amalfi that you need to do and see if they are open/
available. Many people will say, and I agree, eliminate the far south or the far north and maximize what is left if you are on a tight travel time. As for flights, cheaper to arrive and leave from the same airport but open-jaw flights give you less travel and more enjoyment. Purchase your tickets from the airline direct and look to not change planes in Europe but fly direct from your country if possible. Yes, the price goes up a bit, but the convenience is worth it. You mentioned Venice, it really is amazing and something teenagers will love. Easy to open-jaw. March weather will be unpredictable, but you take that chance. Last, don't look at Italy as this is a one- time trip and I have to see it all but look at Italy as the most amazing experience you all will have, and you will come back again. Side note, I am returning to Rome and doing a day trip to Pompeii by train. I just have to see it and with 7 full days in Rome last fall, there just wasn't enough time.
You certainly don't want to miss Venice - find a way to include it. It is a world treasure, and equally as important as Florence and Rome.

At that time of year I would not use so much of your time in Sorrento. The weather was awful in late May when I was there a few years ago. Naples is wonderful and Pompeii can easily be done as a day trip. I would add Venice to your list.
Not seeing Venice is a big mistake, if you’ve never been there! Only my opinion. I’d also go in later in spring. I was there in early June.. no great crowds .. yet
You can take a day car trip to the Amafi coast. It's great and they stop in several of the little towns

I went in March. It was glorious! Mild temperatures during the day (70-80), and cool in the evenings (50-60'ish). I never needed more than a light jacket. We were in Florence for 2 nights, Tuscany for 3 nights and Cinque Terre for 2 nights. It was wonderful! You need one or 2 nights in Rome at most.

If you guys like to cook, check out Casale Alessandri Umbria. Chef Federico and his wife Louise are amazing chef and hosts. My family spent three days there last month and absolutely loved it.

https://
www.casale-aless
andri.com/
I would recommend you shave something else in order to visit Venice. I promise you, you won't regret it. Venice has so much history, great restaurants, great shopping and just walking in enjoyment.

Italy by train is amazing and easy. Weather wise, it’s a tossup but be sure to bring sweaters, jackets, and rain gear!!! It can be chilly and wet.

One of our best trips to Italy was an arrival into Venice for 3 days at the end of Carnevale, then a train journey, all the way to Rome. That trip also included 2-3 day stays each in Bologna and Florence along the way. We loved it!!

We’ve also cruised from Venice to Barcelona with Italian ports for Sicily, Naples, Rome, and Livorno.

So I say try to keep Venice in your itinerary, if you can.
You can't miss Venice when you're that close. My teenagers can't get enough of it. It's remarkable

You may want to look into a day or two in Bologna. We've stayed at an NH hotel right around the corner from the train station, both alone and with our kids. They all got something from our time there and the food is to die for! I'm not sure where you're coming from or what the weather will be like but starting north where it's colder and ending south where it's warmer might be something to consider. We did south to north at the end of December one year and we were miserably cold, but we live in Florida so we felt it more than most.

Use public transit whenever/
wherever you can...but a car would be nice in Florence and Tuscany. It will be cold so takes plenty of layers. Everyone wants to see everything they can but sometimes it's best to focus. My dad always said if he went back (so second trip) to Italy - he would eat his way from the tip of the boot. I would love to go back and just spend more time in Rome and about a week in a villa on the Amalfi coast because I'm interested in art and the coastline history.

For the car rental from Rome, I suggest you take the train to Orvieto and rent the car there for Tuscany. It’s a very cute hill town and a nice place to visit. You simply take the funicular up to the historic old town. Walk around and see the Duomo and have lunch etc. Then drive out to Tuscany.
I also suggest spending time at an Agritourismo instead of a regular hotel. We stayed 4 nights in one outside of San Gimignano and did day trips from there. Driving through the Val de Orcia is just wonderful.

We stayed in Sorrento and lived it. So easy to get to Pompeii etc…
The ferry to Carpri wasn’t running as it was off season so we didn’t see that.

We went in mid April. Weather was fine. We definitely had more rainy cool days than sunny but our sunny days were great. Pompeii day was beautiful and same for our Colosseum & Palentine hill day in Rome. We just looked at forecast and tried to plan inside activities like Vatican etc on rainy days. Still prefer it to the heat we had this June on our trip this year!

Sounds like a great plan! Main thing is to enjoy yourself since you planned it 😆 Hotels by Spanish Steps in Rome are beautiful. Remember to take an adapter plug for your blow dryer/ flatiron including to charge up iPhone.
Venice was a highlight of our trip-including for our 2 college aged kids. You don't need to spend more than a couple of days there, or even less, but don't miss it!!
SKIP VENICE ??? Are you mad 😠
A good guide book to start with is highly useful.
Suggest using an Agent? It makes life so much easier!

My recommendation is that you shorten your time on Amalfi coast (we were there for a full day and that was quite enough — pretty but lots of tourists) and then hop a train to Sicily (Taormina) - absolutely stunning. Less crowds. We spent 3 nights there which allowed us to also book a private guide tour of Mt Etna. Just a suggestion. You’ll love Italy regardless of where you go. Have fun
Enjoy every minute, be open to modified plans, absorb ALL the Culture. Most of all be flya d eat your way through 🇮🇹 Italy

I agree with your plans with minor exception. Fly into Naples, stay in Sorrento. Get a guide in Pompeii and hire a driver for Amalfi, the roads are treacherous, train to Rome get a Rick Steves book or AAA to research. Go to Florence and base there it is the doorway to Tuscany and you’ll move bags less. Save car rental and hire guides, city driving is crazy and parking is nearly nonexistent. Fly out of Florence.

Nothing to be afraid of but Make copies of all important papers, passports and credit cards just to be safe, use money belts, nothing in rear pockets. Travel safe, eat well, enjoy gelato.
You don’t need 3 days in Rome. 1 is enough. It’s too crowded. Stay longer in Tuscany. Great small towns to tour. Cortona, montepucciano…
Make all reservations and buy. skip the line tickets NOW or ASAP.
Check out B&B Miramare in Agerola…
1 day is not enough anywhere and hard on everyone. Take off a day somewhere else and add it to tuscany.

I’d do 2 days Tuscany, 2 days Florence if you can’t extend overall trip.
You’ve got a fair bit of travel time.
For Amalfi, I liked it down in Amalfi or Positano.

just for a reminder, that 2024 easter will be march 29-31, during that time, usually a bit crowded before or a bit after. I would also consider fly into one city and out of another, this will also save u a lot of time wasted on travel. for me personally I prob would not go mid, north, then south, or like u did south, then mid and north. seems to be u have 14 days. I prob would do rome . then all the north and do south some other time, myself and which is what I have planned. we fly into rome (direct) and out of bologna (easier for my destination). there are a lot to see in rome and tuscany area, and I will also not shave off venice. we have our 3rd base in bologna, and from there I will do verona, venice, Ferrara/Padova/
Vicenza, rimini/San Marino, Ravenna etc. there are more than just the typical spots like rome/florence/
venice.. we stay in rome 5 whole days (again bc rome is more than just the few places that ppl talked about). florence is also a good base (our 2nd base) for lucca/pisa, Siena/San G, or even 5 fishing village (we will not go bc we will be there early dec), will do some other times. I believe what helps me is to decide Italy is not one trip pony, it is a big country with amazing sites that deserve a lot more trips to see them all. not to mention italy has 58 UNESCO sites.
Ischia. An island off Italy. 3 days. The prettiest place inhale ever seen

Haven't been in March but have taken three teenagers. In Rome and Venice there is lots of walking. Mine complained the whole time. You might want to space your walking tours out. Other than that, no matter what you do you will have a great time. Like others have said the high speed train is awesome in Italy take advantage. We included Venice in our trip, not impressed with Venice at all but the island around were Devine. If you can do one of those I would recommend if not it is a 50/50 chance you will like Venice. I happened to not like it , my family didn't either.

I’d be inclined to check when everything opens after the winter, especially in the south. It maybe to do with Easter when the season starts. I lived in Sorrento in 1969. In March it was cold. Snow on Vesuvius. With climate change it could be unsettled. The south is beautiful. Certainly summer months is busy. Venice even in the rain is magical (especially with few tourists). A lovely film to watch to get you in the mood for Venice is Katherine Hepburn I think it’s called Summertime or Summer Madness. Brilliant and for Ischia/
Sorrento ‘Avanti with Jack Lemmon and Juliet mills. Still on Amazon. Enjoy and prepare yourself for a real experience 🍋

We just vacationed in Italy earlier this month. I think your itinerary looks perfect. I do recommend staying in Sorrento and then taking tours down the Amalfi coast. We stayed about 5 minutes from the Pantheon and loved it. You’re wise not to get a car in the major cities. Don’t plan to drive into Florence. Consider taking the train to Florence from Rome and then taking day trips into Tuscany
My boys 19 & 23 liked climbing the tower in Pisa. You can do in a half day tour from Florence or as part of a whole day tour.
Get a Frommers book

Sounds fun! I’m planning my trip myself as well- learning so much. First please purchase a good reliable Italy travel guide- I’m using Rick Steve’s Italy guide book- also watching Ricks utube videos as well as so many other utube videos guides on Italy- a wealth of information! Planning is vital to your trips success. The areas you listed are assessable by train or bus- I suggest you get Rome2Rio app- great for travel info. Rome & Florence are every accessible to travel to- the Tuscan countryside - some are easy to travel to by train or bus- use Rome2Rio to find best options. Some other Tuscany towns are not easy accessible by public transport- could look into group tours. Prepare for possible rain - but you’ll be going when there’s less crowds- and less expensive. Have fun planning!
Danny Regalado

We have visited Sorrento, Puglia, Amalfi coast and Rome in March several times. We absolutely love it. We found plenty of restaurants open as well as the ferries to Capri. In the morning and evenings it would be a little cool, mid day 50’s 60’s. It was perfect. You may have a little rain here and there but nothing to be nervous about. I bring a waterproof jacket with a liner. For us Venice was miserable in March. It flooded, the stink, omg, it was our least favorite place.
Have a great trip!

We are doing 11 nights this sept. Flying into Rome and taking train direct to Florence then 4 nights there with some day tours and cooking class, train to Naples and car to Sorrento. Four nights there with a tour to Capri and Positano. Will also see Pompeii. Train back to Rome for last three nights, early private tours of Vatican and coliseum. You have three more nights so you should be fine. I booked private tours and drivers. First class train tickets, transfers, etc.. we are taking our two adult kids and a SO.
Following … I’m just planning now for October 2023 😬
We had a car - stayed near San Gimignano and did one day trip to Lucca and Pisa. One to Siena. We spent a week in Tuscany. Enjoy
We had amazing weather in Rome in February.

We went at just this time ….this year… It was great just a light jacket… No sweating… Crowds weren’t bad either… Check out when Easter is …..you ￼￼ should try to end your travel the week before Easter…
Five whole days in rome must get pretty boring

I agree with those saying your time in Florence would be too much and adding Venice. Our teenagers didn’t like Florence much and wish we would have skipped and added to Venice and Capri. They loved both. Don’t skip Venice.

The weather is good in March. Might rain a little but no big deal. Try to fly into Naples, you can take a ferry to Sorrento for the day. Light hiking can be done in Pompeii. I find that u can walk a lot in Europe so you might not want to hiking to much.

Just re the planning stage - have a quick check of hotels open on the Amalfi coast - many are seasonal and open from May to Oct. which is also common around the coastal areas and lake Como .
That way you can decide which direction you travel .
As a lot of hotels are smaller family owned . Old towns and not high volume of rooms. Chain hotels would stay open, but they are not always located right in the towns due their size.

Depending on how much luggage you have you might be better off basing yourself on Florence and taking day trip or hire car for a day or two. No need to move luggage.
Pompeii is easily reachable by train from Sorrento.
March weather can go either way. I wouldn’t worry about the shops and restaurants being open. They will be and will be happy you are there.
I wouldn't skip Venice. You can take early train there from Florence and do just a day trip.
Try to include Venice.
Ive heard getting to Tuscany is quite the trip, may want to look more into staying longer.
It'll be such a shame to skip Venice. Also, avoid driving because the train is so easy and the schedule is frequent.
Don’t forget you’ll need to do your ETIAS for 2024 and don’t skip Venice - it is magical 💙

Plenty of good advice from others here. Pompeii is a huge site so I recommend get there early in the day and carry water, you could be there for 4 hours and it can get exhausting walking around when hungry (and teenagers…).

You should give a listen to the latest episode of the UnTold Italy Podcast may give some ideas for your itinerary. Remember this is your family’s vacation and not the vacation of the members of this group. Do your homework and plan accordingly or even consider consulting an Italian Travel professional
Scrap it all and spend all of it in Tuscany 🥰

Copied from another group but it explains a bit about beaches

“Beaches in Italy: What to Know Before You Go”

By Karen in Calabria

When a country is almost entirely surrounded by water, as is the case with Italy, it stands to reason that beaches are a big deal. There are beaches of varying degrees of wonderful up and down both sides of The Boot, and the vast majority of Italians grow up with the understanding that part of every summer involves time spent at the shore.

It sounds idyllic, no?

Traveling to Italy in summer is the perfect time to get in on this Italian beach culture, not least because it can be agonizingly hot and humid in the cities. Spontaneity when planning a summer trip to an Italian beach isn’t usually a good thing, however. Those who plan ahead in this department are the ones who reap the rewards.
Which is why you’re here, you clever planner, you.

So, here’s what you need to know about the beaches in Italy, before you don your suit and head for the sand.

"Private" beaches in Italy

I’ve spent most of my life in Oregon, where all beaches are public by law. For me, then, this is one of the aspects of Italian beach culture that surprised me most.

While, technically, the beaches themselves are “public” (and the strip of land right at the water’s edge is certainly that), there are concessions (called “stabilimenti” or “bagni”) at nearly every stretch of sand that have bought permits from local authorities to set up rows and rows of beach chairs (“lettini,” or beds) and umbrellas (“ombrelle”) that they then rent out. Again, technically, while anyone should be able to walk to the water from further up on the beach, the bagni are usually set up so close together – one group of colored umbrellas abutting the next – that passing between them is impossible. And walking through one of them without paying isn’t permitted by the folks running that particular concession.

You may hear about protestors fighting this, demanding more access to beaches, but it doesn’t seem to change the status quo.

So, if you choose to pay for the privilege of hanging out on an Italian beach, what do you get for your money? Quite a bit, actually. Not only do you have a comfy lounge chair and shade-providing umbrella set up for you (without the need to lug one around yourself), you are also granted access to the facilities at the stabilimento – usually including changing rooms, showers, toilets, places to store your clothes, and places to get food and beverages. There are also typically lifeguards on duty.

You can choose just a chair, or a chair with an umbrella, for different fees – and if you’ll be in town for awhile, you can also buy a pass good for a longer period of time. Many Italians have annual rentals at the same bagni, where they get a monthly pass – and therefore the best spots. And yes, when you pay for access to the private beach you’ll be directed toward a chair – you don’t get to choose.

"Public" Beaches in Italy

The rest of the beaches in Italy are entirely public, and therefore free. These are, perhaps unsurprisingly, not always as nice, clean, or well-maintained as the “private” beaches. You can look for signs indicating which beaches or parts of the beach are free (look for the words “spiaggia libera”), but it’s a good bet that the areas without orderly rows of umbrellas and loungers are public beaches.

There’s a huge variance among public beaches in terms of what amenities are available. Some of them have public toilets and showers. There are often beachside restaurants or kiosks nearby, even if they’re just temporary affairs set up for the summer months. Sometimes, however, there is simply a stretch of sand (or pebbles) and that’s it. In many cases, access to the public beach is via a long staircase from a parking area up above, so be prepared for something of a hike. If you’re unfamiliar with the area, it’s a good idea to inquire about the facilities before you head out, lest you arrive for a day at the beach without necessary provisions.

It’s also a good idea to keep a close eye on your belongings, especially on busy public beaches. These are not monitored by anyone, so would-be pickpockets and petty thieves sometimes meander through looking for easy targets. Make sure it’s not you.

Italian Beach Attire

Perhaps you’re familiar with the often-comically-portrayed stereotype of old Italian men at the beach in Speedos, letting a lifetime’s worth of pasta gut all hang out. Stereotypes usually have at least some basis in fact, and – yes – those guys exist. In fact, the Speedo-type suit is still de rigeur for many older Italian (and European) men. More common these days, however, especially for younger men, are swim trunks.

For women of all ages, a bikini or two-piece is the way to go. One-piece suits are something of a rarity on Italian beaches, no matter one’s age or body type. (Italian women think “bikini body” means “any body on which you put a bikini,” which is a million kinds of wonderful, if you ask me.)

In some parts of Italy, topless sunbathing is common and not restricted to certain beaches or areas – bare breasts not being seen as the taboo that they seem to be in the United States. Nude sunbathing, however, is usually restricted to certain areas that may or may not be specially-designated as nude beaches (they may be unofficially categorized as such, in that locals all know where the invisible boundary is). If you’re looking for (or trying to avoid) a nude beach, ask around. And before you take off your top on any beach, it’s a good idea to make sure you’re not the only one doing so – just in case you’re in a part of the country where that’s not such an accepted norm. As in many other situations, best practice is to follow the lead of the locals.

Italy is nothing if not fashionable, and that extends to beach vacations. Even in beach towns, you won’t see people walking into restaurants or shops wearing flip-flops or bikini tops. Beach attire is for the beach, and that’s that. Men, top off your stylish (and dry) swim trunks with an equally-stylish tee shirt. Women, put on a pretty sundress or beach cover-up dress over your swimsuit. And everyone, swap the plastic beach sandals for something a bit nicer.

August on an Italian Beach

Many Italians and other Europeans get about a month of vacation time each summer, often in August. And if you’ve ever seen an Italian beach in August, you might think every single last one of them spends that vacation on a beach in Italy.

Yeah, beaches in Italy in August are crowded.
Remember earlier when I said that as fun as a spontaneous day trip to that pretty Italian beach in August sounds, it isn’t necessarily a good idea? This is why. Because so many people spend a few weeks at the seaside every single summer, you bet they’ve booked well in advance – everything from their hotel or apartment to their beach chairs.

This isn’t to say that you shouldn’t go to the beach in the summer if you’re in Italy – far from it. It just means that you’ll be far happier doing so if you can plan ahead a bit. Book lodging in advance, and – if you can – arrange for spots at a stabilimento. Make your time at the beach as relaxing as it ought to be with a little advance legwork.

Blue Flag Beaches

The Blue Flag program is a global environmental effort that gives out its Blue Flag awards to beaches and marinas that meet its list of more than 30 criteria (including water quality, services available, and overall safety). There are so-called Blue Flag beaches all over the world, including many in Italy.

The list of Blue Flag beaches in Italy changes periodically, as the sites are regularly evaluated by the organization, with existing beaches removed and new ones added.

Hello all,
I have always booked holidays using different sites and paying one-off.
This is the 1st time I have reserved directly with hotel in Milan. They just asked for credit card details n payment will be done on arrival.
Can anyone explain how does this work?
I am travelling from Uk.
Thank you.

comments.comment_text: Just like it sounds…you pay when you get there. If using credit card be sure to have one that doesn’t charge foreign transaction fees. You pay in euros and your card converts it to your home currency
A credit card is required to guarantee your reservation.

I do that all the time. The card holds your room. And when you get there you have an option to pay with the card or cash.
It is the only way I book a room.
I do that in Rome every year, same thing, I think you have a week to cancel if no show they can deduct the amount it costs🌻

Be sure to call several days before your arrival to confirm your reservation. Hotels will run your credit card two or three days before you arrive to see if it is still valid. If there is an issue with it, they may cancel your reservation ￼ and you won’t find out until you arrive. ￼ I found out about this the hard way when my credit card number was stolen and I canceled it. I didn’t think to call the hotel at my next destination to let them know. ￼ They canceled my reservation without notifying me.

You'll need to check the terms and conditions of the booking, but usually you can pay on arrival with card or cash. If you're a no-show though, they might charge a certain amount to the card you provided details of, e.g. the first nights stay.
